4.heading: Temples.
4.title: "Chokha Mela : the Boy Who Heard God"
4.author: script, Kamala Chandrakant ; illustrations, Dilip Kadam ; editor, Anant Pai
4.appears_in: p. 1-29 in Amar Chitra Katha, no. 744 (1983, 2009 printing).
notes: Begins: "One evening towards the close of the thirteenth century, a few Mahar boys were playing hututu outside their huts at Mangalvedha in Solapur district."

Summary from back cover: "Chokha was a young boy when he first heard the call of the Lord. But all attempts to enter temples were thwarted by those who only saw him as a Mahar, an untouchable. However, Chokha's devotion was such that his heart became a temple, and he sang with purity and complete faith. Chokha Mela's Abhangs or verses echo to this day around the temples of Maharashtra."

5.heading: Temples.
5.title: "Dr. Strange, Master of Black Magic!"
5.author: story, Stan Lee ; art, Steve Ditko ; lettering, Terry Szenics
5.appears_in: 5 p. in Strange Tales, no. 110 (July 1963); reprinted in Marvel Collectors' Item Classics, no. 3 (June 1966); reprinted in Origins of Marvel Comics (New York : Simon and Schuster, 1974)
notes: SUMMARY: Traveling in the astral plane, here called the "dimension of dreams," Dr. Strange visits his master at a temple high in a mountain somewhere in Asia (Tibet or Nepal?) and helps an unscrupulous businessman find out why he can't sleep at night. I. [Each creator] k. Astral plane. k. Dimension of dreams. k. Masters. k. Temples. k. Asia. k. Tibet. k. Nepal. k. Unscrupulous businessmen. k. Businessmen. k. Sleep. k. Dreams. k. Master of Black Magic. k. Black magic. k. Magic. Call no.: PN6728.2.M3S75no.110

6.heading: Temples.
6.title: "Ellora Caves : the Glory of the Rashtrakootas"
6.author: script, H
6.appears_in: Atmaram ; illustrations, Ramanand Bhagat ; editor, Anant Pai. p. 1-29 in Amar Chitra Katha, no. 731 (1988, 2009 printing).
notes: Summary from back cover: "The Rashtrakootas who ruled in Decan for two and a half centuries (752 to 982 AD) respected all faiths of their time. This is reflected in Ellora where we find rock-cut cave-temples representing the Vaishnava, Shaiva, Jaina and Buddhist faiths. This Amar Chitra Katha tells the story of the Rashtrakoota heroes who have left us a lasting legacy, the Ellora Caves.
Splash title: "The Glory of the Rashtrakootas."

7.heading: Temples.
7.title: "Hopes of Finishing Their Round in Four Hours Quickly Faded"
7.author: by John McPherson.
notes: Summary: The foursome ahead has sculpted an elaborate temple in the sand trap.

8.heading: Temples.
8.title: "I Didn't Even Know You Were Jewish"
8.author: J
notes: Summary: Alex says his body is a temple.

9.heading: Temples.
9.title: "In the Temple of Cartoon Gods"
9.author: Art Spiegelman
9.appears_in: back cover of Legal Action Comics. v. 1 (New York : Dirty Danny Legal Defense Fund, 2001).

10.heading: Temples.
10.title: "Jagannatha of Puri : Dreamt by a King, Sculpted by the Gods"
10.author: script, Gayatri Modan Dutt ; illustrations, Souren Roy ; editor, Anant Pai
10.appears_in: p. 1-31 in Amar Chitra Katha, no. 709 (1983, 2009 printing).
notes: Summary from back cover: "King Indradyumna of Utkal had only one wish, to be able to build a temple that would be the most beautiful in the world. His quest was for the image of the blue-coloured Krishna or Nilamadhav. The king came very close to achieving his goal but his pride and arrogance snatched it away from him leaving him groping once more in the dark. Contained in this Amar Chitra Katha is the legend behind the temple of Jagannathapuri in Orissa and the images enshrined in it."

11.heading: Temples.
11.title: "Kui"
11.author: story & art, Alex Toth
notes: "The plane splashed into the ocean. Waves parted gracefully and it was on the beach, shining silver in the tropical sun. Then he and Louise climbed out and began their long ascent, to find the legendary Kui, cursed temple of the inaccessible god!"

12.heading: Temples.
12.title: "Lest We Forget!"
12.author: by Major T
12.appears_in: E. Bowen. 10 p. in Wings Comics, no. 112 (1950) ; partial rewrite of untitled Captain Wings story in Wings Comics, no. 58 (June 1945).
notes: Summary: In an air battle, Captain Wings has killed Prince Yuima-Koji, the son of the Japanese emperor. Intelligence officer Madam Dragon asks for one last chance to capture Captain Wings. Posing as an exotic dancer she captures his men while they're off-duty in Katung, and drops one of them back at the base, dead but with a letter attached. Captain Wings is instructed to exchange himself for the rest of the men. It's a trap, at a temple in the country, but Captain Wings goes anyhow. Just as the men are about to be cremated alive in Prince Yuima-Koji's plane, Griper shows up, kills Madam Dragon and blows up the temple.

13.heading: Temples.
13.title: "The Loot in the Temple"
13.author: [No author]
13.series: Capt. Courageous) 8 p. in Four Favorites, no. 22

14.heading: Temples.
14.title: "The Lord of Cats" p. 13-23 in The Three Ears
14.author: Alejandro Jodorowsky - Georges Bess ; translation by Justin Kelly.
notes: Summary: Gabriel begins his life as a novice monk by vanquishing the reigning bully, Topden. The next night, after a horde of cats has been brought in to watch the temple, the Topden wants to be friends and shows Gabriel how to get past the cats by giving them mice. Gabriel refuses to sacrifice the mice, but rather makes friends with the top cat, named Lin-Fa.

16.heading: Temples.
16.title: "Madhvacharya : A Vaishnava Saint-Philosopher"
16.author: script, B
16.appears_in: N.K. Sharma ; illustrations, H.S. Chavan ; editor, Anant Pai. p. 1-32 in Amar Chitra Katha, no. 579 (1978, 2009 printing).
notes: Begins: "A vast number of devotees had gathered at the ancient temple of Ananteshwara in Udupi for the annual festival."

Summary from back cover: "Madhvacharya (ca. 1238-1317) propagated the Bhakti Marg or the path of devotion for God realisation. He felt no need to deny the world to realise God. Relying on logic, and quoting profusely from the scriptures, he made a strong case for theism. His school of thought is known as dvaita which stands for two realities: independent and dependent. The infinitely perfect God is independent and the world of matter and spirits is dependent on God. he advocated total surrender to God to achieve salvation."

26.heading: Temples.
26.title: "Swami Chinmayananda : Modern Life Meets Ancient Wisdom"
26.author: script, Margie Sastry ; illustrations, Dilip Kadam ; editor, Anant Pai
26.appears_in: p. 1-30 in Amar Chitra Katha, no. 732 (2001, 2009 printing).
notes: Summary from back cover: "Nurtured on modern learning and ancient wisdom as a child, he taught himself to meditate even as he dreamed of dinner, skipped out of family visits to the temple but spent hours in soliltary prayer, and campaigned for India's freedom while aiming for a master's degree in English literature. 'Chinmaya' means true knowledge, and it is what Swami Chinmayananda taught the world."

61.heading: Templeton, Plabo.
61.title: Ma Dalton [videorecording]
61.author: a production of Paloma Films and Reteitalia Production ; directed by Richard Schlesinger ; executive producer, Lucio Bompani ; written by Carl Sautter.
notes: Performers: Terence Hill, Nancy Morgan, Fritz Sperberg, Dominic Barto, Bo Gray, Radha Delamarter, Marc Mouchet, Neil Summers, Plabo Templeton, Ron Carey, Ruth Buzzi.
Based on Ma Dalton by Morris and Goscinny from the "Lucky Luke" comic books.
Television series (1993?) created by Lori Hill and Carl Sautter.

Summary (from OCLC): With the Dalton Brothers behind bars, Luke plans on getting a little rest. On returning to Daisy Town, Luke finds out that the outlaw's mother Ma Dalton has been robbing all the shopkeepers in the area. They have been letting her get away with her crimes because they know she is too proud to beg for charity. Luke and Ma Dalton becomes friends and Luke is more or less adopted by Ma. When Joe Dalton hears that his Ma has a new "son" he is furious and breaks out of prison with his brothers. Joe is chained to Bushwack, the "dumbest guard dog in the West" so every time Bushwack chases something Joe goes for a painful ride. Luke is caught between the Dalton boys and their Ma with the lovely Lotta wanting some of his attentions as well.

Mireille Ribière & Jan Baetens).

158.title: "Temps Partagés, Temps Retrouvés : Lecture sous Influence"
158.author: Hugues de Chanay
158.appears_in: p. 90-94 in 9e Art : les Cahiers du Musée de la Bande Dessinée, no. 9 (Oct. 2003).
notes: Begins: "Les quelques réflexions qui suivent sont nées du plaisir pris à la lecture du Journal de Fabrice Neaud. Remontant à la source de ce plaisir, j'ai cru y trouver des polyphonies temporelles et une empathie somatique: mots un peu opaques que je vais tâcher d'éclaircir"

English summary (from p. 127): "Time Shared, Time Recalled. Hugues de Chanay hypothesizes that Neaud's diary is deliberately conceived in such a way as to create an interior rhythm of thought in the reader. He examines the manner in which the time of the events recounted mingles with that of remembrance and of the real time of reading, these three planes intermixing on both pictorial and linguistic levels."
